displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, uh, they’ll just tell you what to worry about, what not to worry about, what fevers we worry about, what numbers to call, uh, what you can eat, what you don’t eat sometimes. I don’t know what the class really is about. Patient: Okay. Family Member: So, S_ had, um, he was getting chemo, he had a bathroom that nobody was supposed to use. Doctor: They’ll talk to you about that and teach it in the class, but I don’t think that’s an issue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, what, what other questions do you have? Patient: I read the, the, the information which you gave me. I - trepeditation about the, my actual response to all of this. And, I won’t know that until we start. So. I really don’t have anything other than - I wanna get it started. It’s my fourth visit, and you’re a great guy. But, next time, I want you to stick a needle in my arm or something. Doctor: Yeah. So, yeah we, you know, my problem with this stuff is, you know, the hormone therapy does good on it’s own. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we are adding more into it, so we can’t always tell you what the, um, adding in the chemo is gonna do. We can’t tell you what the surgery is gonna do. But, the outcome really is a number of men that don’t need therapy once we stop everything. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s not a great utility for us at this moment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But sometimes if we find that it’s useful later we certainly can. Yeah. Family Member: Now do you think after three months, after he’s on medication, what scans will you be taking? Will you be taking like the - Doctor: The CAT scan.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: I mean yeah living, dining area, a little kitchenette. You go down the hall with two bedrooms and a bathroom at the end. It’s nicer than, it’s bigger than my one at home, at home. Doctor: Oh, my, gosh. Patient: I don’t know if I still have it- Doctor: Wait a minute. So is this? Patient: B___’s house. Yeah. Doctor: This is B___’s house? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you see him or is he on tour? Patient: I saw, no, you know, he’s having some uh medical problems Doctor: Oh, no. Patient: Are we in the cone of silence here? Doctor: Well, you’re on. Hey. Could you guys, can you guys put down the thingy? The, the cut this part out? Patient: Uh, I can tell you, I can tell you when we’re walking out.

Patient: Well, besides that, huh, that pain I’m still getting. Except for now I’m getting a pain right here. I’m thinking this is from this. I’m not sure. But, huh- Doctor: So where’s the pain at that you had before? Patient: Down in here. Doctor: In your buttock? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or it’s hips and buttock? Patient: Hip. Doctor: Okay. Huh, okay, and, huh, any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And how’s your headaches been? Patient: One side of pain right here, I don’t have any. Doctor: And no trouble swallowing?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Well, I, you know, I, I totally live, chemo would be logistically a problem. You know? I mean I’m, you know, I kind of dread it. I do. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I kind of knew it was coming but uh. What do you think the duration of that? Doctor: Of the treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So on a trial, it’s for eight treatments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C.

Patient: No. Doctor: Holding his own, getting worse, better? Family Member: I think he’s basically holding his own. Family Member 1: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And I see you still use a cane? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Anything new on your body you want me to take a look at? Bumps, lumps? Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything?

Patient: Yeah, I want to say I have maybe, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because the other thought is Dr. S____ is here today, right? Healthcare Professional: Yes? Doctor: We have our own pain person. So, that way Family Member: Yay Doctor: if we have to transition, you’re right here too. Ah hah. So, you don’t have to Family Member: Right. Doctor: go running off somewhere. Okay, that sounds good Dr. H____, let’s do it. Patient: I mean that works for me. Doctor: Ok, that’s it. Patient: I mean since I got to come here anyway. Doctor: Yes and honestly I think your pain sometimes gets worse because you’re anemic Patient: Yeah, I mean it’s

Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right.

Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that is a specialized scan that is done either in Texas or in New York. Family Member: Yeah. We talked about that. Doctor: So you would have to go over there to get that scan before we can even decide if you should get the study or not. Family Member: So he’d have to have some blood work? Is it a blood draw? Is it, uh-? Doctor: For what?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Yep. Doctor: A pro-antibiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Calcium or Vitamin B once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Cranberry extract once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Vitamin B-twelve once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You know. You have a drug, so it’s one pill each morning. Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on.

Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence. Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month.

Family Member: And basically that’s what we are doing. He’s mostly had chicken, fish, uh. Now I occasionally I prepare, cook. Is pork okay? Doctor: Uh hum. Just lean cuts. Family Member: Lean cuts. How about lamb, can he have that? Doctor: Sure, lean cuts. Family Member: Lean cuts, no beef. Doctor: He can have beef, a little lean, just in moderation, not the fatty kind. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. Family Member: Okay, okay. Is it, did it matter if he’s gluten free not? Doctor: Yeah, there isn’t anything about gluten-free diets and prostate cancer. You know how he feels on having the gluten uh. It’s not an association with prostate cancer. Family Member: And cancer in general? Doctor: You can that way.
